dataset_id: ABoVE: Distribution Maps of Wildland Fire Fuel Components across Alaskan Tundra, 2015
title: ABoVE: Distribution Maps of Wildland Fire Fuel Components across Alaskan Tundra, 2015
summary: This dataset provides maps of the distribution of three major wildland fire fuel types at 30 m spatial resolution covering the Alaskan arctic tundra, circa 2015. The three fuel components include woody (evergreen and deciduous shrubs), herbaceous (sedges and grasses), and nonvascular species (mosses and lichens). Multi-seasonal and multispectral mosaics were first developed at 30 m resolution using Landsat 8 surface reflectance data collected from 2013 to 2017. The spectral information from Landsat mosaics was combined with field observations from representative tundra vegetation plots collected during multiple field trips to model the fractional cover of fuel type components. An improved vegetation mask for shrub and graminoid-dominated tundra was developed using random forest classification and is also included. The final fractional cover maps were developed using the trained model with the multi-seasonal and multi-spectral Landsat mosaics across the entire Alaskan tundra.

cmr.ScienceKeywords4: EARTH SCIENCE@LAND SURFACE@LAND USE/LAND COVER@LAND RESOURCES

citation: Beamish, A., M.K. Raynolds, H. Epstein, G.V. Frost, M.J. Macander, H. Bergstedt, A. Bartsch, S. Kruse, V. Miles, C.M. Tanis, B. Heim, M. Fuchs, S. Chabrillat, I. Shevtsova, M. Verdonen, and J. Wagner. 2020. Recent trends and remaining challenges for optical remote sensing of Arctic tundra vegetation: A review and outlook. Remote Sensing of Environment. 246:111872.
